items.title: No support for !Sub and other AWS-like yaml extensions
items.body:
I have no idea whether tehse are "standard" yaml or not, but it would be super useful if this supported the !XXX yaml extensions that AWS uses. eg:

```
  LambdaExecRolePolicies:
    Type: AWS::IAM::Policy
    Properties:
      PolicyName: !Sub '${OwnerNamespace}-${AssetNamespace}-execution-${FunctionName}'

```
This currently results in the following stack trace:

>   LambdaExecRolePolicies:
>     Type: AWS::IAM::Policy
>     Properties:
>       PolicyName: !Sub '${OwnerNamespace}-${AssetNamespace}-execution-${FunctionName}'
>  ❯ cat ig1xm-iam.yaml | shyaml get-value AWSTemplateFormatVersion
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "/usr/local/bin/shyaml", line 459, in <module>
>     sys.exit(main(sys.argv[1:]))
>   File "/usr/local/bin/shyaml", line 397, in main
>     contents = yaml.load(sys.stdin)
>   File "/usr/local/Cellar/shyaml/0.5.2_1/libexec/lib/python3.7/site-packages/yaml/__init__.py", line 72, in load
>     return loader.get_single_data()
>   File "/usr/local/Cellar/shyaml/0.5.2_1/libexec/lib/python3.7/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 37, in get_single_data
>     return self.construct_document(node)
>   File "/usr/local/Cellar/shyaml/0.5.2_1/libexec/lib/python3.7/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 41, in construct_document
>     data = self.construct_object(node)
>   File "/usr/local/Cellar/shyaml/0.5.2_1/libexec/lib/python3.7/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 86, in construct_object
>     data = constructor(self, node)
>   File "/usr/local/bin/shyaml", line 119, in construct_omap
>     return MyOrderedDict(cls.construct_pairs(node))
>   File "/usr/local/Cellar/shyaml/0.5.2_1/libexec/lib/python3.7/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 141, in construct_pairs
>     value = self.construct_object(value_node, deep=deep)
>   File "/usr/local/Cellar/shyaml/0.5.2_1/libexec/lib/python3.7/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 86, in construct_object
>     data = constructor(self, node)
>   File "/usr/local/bin/shyaml", line 119, in construct_omap
>     return MyOrderedDict(cls.construct_pairs(node))
>   File "/usr/local/Cellar/shyaml/0.5.2_1/libexec/lib/python3.7/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 141, in construct_pairs
>     value = self.construct_object(value_node, deep=deep)
>   File "/usr/local/Cellar/shyaml/0.5.2_1/libexec/lib/python3.7/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 86, in construct_object
>     data = constructor(self, node)
>   File "/usr/local/bin/shyaml", line 119, in construct_omap
>     return MyOrderedDict(cls.construct_pairs(node))
>   File "/usr/local/Cellar/shyaml/0.5.2_1/libexec/lib/python3.7/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 141, in construct_pairs
>     value = self.construct_object(value_node, deep=deep)
>   File "/usr/local/Cellar/shyaml/0.5.2_1/libexec/lib/python3.7/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 86, in construct_object
>     data = constructor(self, node)
>   File "/usr/local/bin/shyaml", line 119, in construct_omap
>     return MyOrderedDict(cls.construct_pairs(node))
>   File "/usr/local/Cellar/shyaml/0.5.2_1/libexec/lib/python3.7/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 141, in construct_pairs
>     value = self.construct_object(value_node, deep=deep)
>   File "/usr/local/Cellar/shyaml/0.5.2_1/libexec/lib/python3.7/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 86, in construct_object
>     data = constructor(self, node)
>   File "/usr/local/Cellar/shyaml/0.5.2_1/libexec/lib/python3.7/site-packages/yaml/constructor.py", line 414, in construct_undefined
>     node.start_mark)
> yaml.constructor.ConstructorError: could not determine a constructor for the tag '!Sub'
>   in "<stdin>", line 34, column 19
> 
I realize this is a super-specific case, but from a user case POV, it's not uncommon.

items.title: Not all heroes wear capes
items.body:
This isn't a bug, but a compliment.  

You really saved my day.  Great tool. 

Thanks a lot!

items.title: Missing args do not raise informative error.
items.body:
Aha, so I was not told of my error where I provided insufficient args?
Two args are required?

$ cat file | shyaml -y get-value <VALUE_NAME>

**All I wanted was a way to validate the yaml file, ONLY.**

As per bash, return code of 0 would be GOOD.
As per bash, return code of 1 would be BAD.  :)

Let's see if we can work together a bit?
- jeremy


NOTE:  My original email to you documented this issue in a gist...
https://gist.github.com/jeremy-donson/204b27e59f111f63b95830df7797789b

items.title: shyaml tries to construct objects from the input YAML
items.body:
i wanted to use shyaml to iterate through a YAML file that contains encrypted Ansible Vault values, which are represented by objects, however the YAML loader tries to instantiate the corresponding object (represented by the `!vault` tag) and subsequently fails.

The script throws the following exception:

> yaml.constructor.ConstructorError: could not determine a constructor for the tag '!vault'

items.title: installation on user space on cluster
items.body: Hi, I successfully managed to install shymal on my personal machine using `pip`. However, I need it when running jobs on a batch farm to which I have access. From my user space on the cluster, I issued `$ pip install --user shyaml`, as I usually do to install pip packages there. The installation ended successfully, however it did not generate the executable in the bin folder (even because I don't have a local/bin/ folder). The installation only generated a `shyaml-0.5.0.dist-info/` folder in `.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages`. Is there a way to have it running in my circumstance? Thank you very much

items.title: Highly unlikely UnicodeEncodeError
items.body:
locale en_US.UTF-8
/usr/bin/env python ->Python 2.7.9
python-yaml 3.11-2
shyaml/master

```yaml
non-ascii: Zoltán
```

```bash
#!/bin/bash

echo "$(shyaml get-value non-ascii < s.yml)"

shyaml get-value non-ascii < s.yml
```

```
Traceback (most recent call last):

    print(dump(value), end='')
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xe1' in position 4: ordinal not in range(128)

Zoltán
```

Please advise.

items.title: Inconsistency with ``get-value`` outputing either YAML or literal string
items.body:
Most of the time, the output from ``get-value`` can be re-used as YAML and piped again into
``shyaml``. For anything else than ``str`` type, this is consistent. But it is not for ``str``:

    cat <<EOF > test.yml
    a: |
        this is a string with a semicolon: it should remain
        a string with semicolon.
    EOF

I'm expecting that:

    cat test.yml | shyaml get-type a

and

    cat test.yml | shyaml get-value a |  shyaml get-type

give the same value.

The second crashes.

So it seems that we need a ``shyaml get-value`` that outputs YAML quoted strings. This problem comes from the ``dump`` function used in ``shyaml get-value`` and all over the place. This function is indeed breaking YAML compatibility clearly, by refusing ``yaml.dump`` to print the correct value.

Of course, backwards compatibility is important, so we can't just change the behavior of ``get-value``, but we might want to add for instance a ``-y`` or ``--yaml`` when we are sure we want YAML only.

items.title: doesn't support multiple documents
items.body: In the case of multiple documents in a yaml stream, it would be great to be able to use shyaml to parse and extract data via pipe.

items.title: py2 or py3 errors on the following
items.body:

[foo.yml.txt](https://github.com/0k/shyaml/files/587121/foo.yml.txt)

and either python2.7 or python3.5, the examples on get, keys-0, etc. all seem to fail in various ways.

The example file loads fine in python yaml.

items.title: UTF-8 characters get ISO-8859-1 encoded
items.body:
Locale is en_US.utf8
Python v2.7.9

``` yaml
system:
    fqdn: host.domain.tld
    os: Debian jessie
    hosting-company: Provider
    install-date: 2016-MM-DD
    trespass-warning: |
                        *
                        *** Ez a szerver ${COMPANY} használatában áll. Másoknak a belépés tilos. ***
                        *
```

```
# shyaml get-value system.trespass-warning < server.yml
"*\n*** Ez a szerver ${COMPANY} haszn\xE1lat\xE1ban \xE1ll. M\xE1soknak a bel\xE9\
  p\xE9s tilos. ***\n*\n"
```

@vaab Please advise.

items.title: Fail on complex array
items.body:
It seems that if the yaml file contains a complex list like:
 package:
        ? - php5-mcrypt
          - php5-curl
          - php5-gd
          - php5-mysqlnd
          - locales
        : ensure: present

It will through an exception.

Wonder if there is an easy fix for it?

Thanks!

items.title: Support python3
last version does not clearly states dependency to ``ordereddict`` in python 2.6
items.body: Can we put this in `setup.py` or avoid failing at least. This is a regression for python `2.6`.

items.title: Get collection length
items.body: I have been having some issues trying to parse collections of structs.  I noticed the ability to access lists using dotted integers, but couldn't find a way to find the length.  The addition of a 'get-length'  command for collections would make iteration over lists of unknown sizes with possibly unknown contents much much easier (at least when scripting).

items.title: Exit code != 0 when key not found
items.body:
When trying to get a key from a data structure and there is a possiblity that the key do not exists, i will not get a exit code (1 for example) that the key was not found. Currently i can only use a DEFAULT value and check if the default value was returned or not and assume it was a error then.

But this could be bad becuase i have to invent my own default value that would not collide with the possible values that the key could have if it would exist. Say for example i choose DEFAULT=-1 but it would break if it would be allowed to have -1 as a value for my key if it was defined.

To have `sys.exit(1)` runned in case the key is not found or similar error would be good i think.

items.title: Ignore errors when keys do not exists
items.body:
When asking for mutliple depth key, it could be convenient to not display any errors in such cases:

```
$ echo "" | shyaml get-values-0 manifest.include-charm
```

And simply return nothing. Note that I can redirect stderr to /dev/null, so this is a very minor issue.

items.title: shyaml keys show function dump representations
items.body:
I use the test.yaml from README in the example shyaml keys. The same happens with my custom yaml file (I cannot put that here). I use commit d35421826a0fb8dc8c02183beb65622fa29d883f
installed via python setup.py install

```
cat test.yaml | shyaml keys
<function dump at 0x7f526cac3938>
<function dump at 0x7f526cac3938>
<function dump at 0x7f526cac3938>
<function dump at 0x7f526cac3938>
<function dump at 0x7f526cac3938>
```

items.title: How return error when a key does not exist?
items.body:
Suppose that I have the following `test.yaml` file.

```
name: "MyName !!"
subvalue:
    how-much: 1.1
    things:
        - first
        - second
        - third
    other-things: [a, b, c]
    maintainer: "Valentin Lab"
    description: |
        Multiline description:
        Line 1
        Line 2
```

The following command would return an exit status of 0 event the key `subvalue.maintainer1` does not exist. Is there a way to have shyaml return an non-zero status in such a case? Thanks.

```
~$ cat test.yaml | shyaml get-value subvalue.maintainer1
~$ echo $?
0
```

items.title: key{,-0} called with no args give an error
items.body:
Hi, many thanks to Yassa Bb who reported me this issue:

These commands, launched on the main `test.yaml` file will trigger an error message:

```
$ cat test.yaml | shyaml keys 
Error: keys does not support 'str' type. Please provide or select a struct.
```

Same occurs with `keys-0`, and `get-value` behave strangely.
